verses.arabic: وَلَمَّا جَاءَهُمْ رَسُولٌ مِّنْ عِندِ اللَّهِ مُصَدِّقٌ لِّمَا مَعَهُمْ نَبَذَ فَرِيقٌ مِّنَ الَّذِينَ أُوتُوا الْكِتَابَ كِتَابَ اللَّهِ وَرَاءَ ظُهُورِهِمْ كَأَنَّهُمْ لَا يَعْلَمُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa lammā jā'ahum rasūlun min 'indi Allāhi muṣaddiqun limā ma'ahum nabadha farīqun mina alladhīna ūtū al-kitāba kitāba Allāhi warā'a ẓuhūrihim ka'annahum lā ya'lamūn
verses.translation: And when a messenger from Allah came to them confirming that which was with them, a party of those who had been given the Scripture threw the Scripture of Allah behind their backs as if they did not know

grammar.function: Connects this verse to previous narrative
grammar.reason: Links this statement about the messenger to the preceding discussion about the People of the Book.
grammar.practical: The simple conjunction 'and'. It continues the narrative flow, connecting what happened when the messenger came to the previous verses. This 'wa' signals: 'and furthermore' or 'and then'.

grammar.reason: Introduces a temporal clause. Unlike 'idhā' (if/when), 'lammā' indicates something that definitely happened in the past.
grammar.practical: Means 'when' in the sense of 'as soon as' or 'the moment that'. This particle tells you something definite happened. It sets up the main clause: WHEN this happened, THEN that occurred. 'Lammā' carries a sense of immediacy and certainty - it's not 'if' but 'when it actually happened'.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Past Tense Verb (Fi'l Māḍī) + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Describes the completed action of the messenger's arrival. The 'hum' suffix shows WHO he came to.
grammar.practical: From the root j-y-' meaning 'to come'. 'Jā'a' = 'he came', and adding 'hum' = 'them' makes it 'he came to them' or 'came to them'. The verb is in past tense (māḍī), showing this actually occurred. Arabic efficiently combines the verb and its object into one word!

grammar.reason: This is the subject who performed the action of coming. The 'un' ending (tanwīn dammah) marks it as the subject and makes it indefinite: 'a messenger'.
grammar.practical: Means 'messenger' or 'one who is sent'. From the root r-s-l (to send). The 'un' ending has two jobs: (1) it marks this as the subject doing the action (coming), and (2) the tanwīn makes it indefinite. Subjects in Arabic take dammah. The tanwīn (double 'n' sound) indicates 'a' messenger, not 'the' messenger, though we know it refers to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ.

grammar.reason: Shows WHERE the messenger is from. The 'min' indicates the source or origin.
grammar.practical: The preposition 'from' - indicates source or origin. Here it tells us the messenger is FROM somewhere important. After 'min', the next word takes kasrah (i ending). Notice the shaddah (doubling mark) on the mīm - it's written as 'min' with emphasis for smooth Quranic recitation.

grammar.root: ع-ن-د ('a-n-d) - to be near, in the presence of
grammar.reason: Indicates presence or proximity. Together with 'min' it means 'from the presence of'. The 'i' ending is due to the preposition 'min'.
grammar.practical: 'Ind' means 'with', 'at', or 'in the presence of'. It's a special word showing location or possession. The 'i' ending (kasrah) is because of the preposition 'min' before it. Together 'min 'indi' = 'from with' or more naturally 'from the presence of'. This emphasizes the messenger's divine origin!

grammar.reason: Follows ''ind' in a possessive construct (iḍāfah). The 'i' ending shows it's in genitive case, meaning 'Allah's presence' or 'from Allah'.
grammar.practical: The blessed name of Allah. Here it ends in 'i' (Allāhi) because it's in a possessive relationship with ''ind'. The phrase ''indi Allāhi' means 'with Allah' or 'from Allah's presence'. Whenever a noun follows another noun in possession, the second noun takes kasrah (i). This construction emphasizes the messenger is not self-appointed - he's FROM ALLAH!

grammar.root: ص-د-ق (ṣ-d-q) - to be truthful, to confirm
grammar.reason: Describes the messenger - it's an adjective modifying 'rasūl'. Form II indicates intensive or repeated action. The 'un' ending matches 'rasūlun' (both are nominative indefinite).
grammar.practical: Active participle meaning 'one who confirms'. From ṣ-d-q (truth). The pattern 'muṣaddiq' (Form II active participle) shows someone who actively, repeatedly confirms. The 'un' ending matches the noun it describes ('rasūlun'). This tells us the messenger's role: he CONFIRMS what came before. Form II often means doing something intensively - here, thoroughly confirming the previous scriptures.

grammar.reason: Indicates WHAT is being confirmed. The preposition 'li' shows relationship, and 'mā' introduces what they possess.
grammar.practical: Combination of 'li' (for/to) + 'mā' (what). Together = 'for what' or 'to what'. The doubling of the lām is a recitation feature. This introduces the object of confirmation: confirming WHAT (they already have). The construction sets up the next phrase about what's with them.

grammar.reason: Indicates possession or accompaniment. Shows the scriptures are IN THEIR POSSESSION. The 'hum' pronoun refers to the People of the Book.
grammar.practical: 'Ma'a' means 'with' in the sense of accompaniment or possession. Adding 'hum' (them) makes 'ma'ahum' = 'with them'. This refers to the Torah and Gospel they possess. So the complete phrase 'muṣaddiqun limā ma'ahum' = 'confirming what is with them' - meaning the Quran confirms the original, uncorrupted message in their scriptures!

grammar.root: ن-ب-ذ (n-b-dh) - to throw away, to reject, to discard
grammar.reason: This is the main verb of the sentence after the 'lammā' clause. It describes what happened WHEN the messenger came - a group threw away the scripture.
grammar.practical: From n-b-dh meaning 'to throw away' or 'to discard'. This is a strong word - not just 'put aside' but actively THREW AWAY. The past tense tells us this is what they actually did. This verb carries connotation of rejection and contempt. In Quranic context, it's used for abandoning something important - here, abandoning Allah's book!

grammar.reason: Subject of the verb 'nabadha'. The 'un' ending marks it as the subject. It's indefinite, meaning 'a group' not all of them.
grammar.practical: Means 'a group' or 'a party' - a portion, not everyone. From f-r-q (to divide/separate). The 'un' ending shows this is the subject who did the throwing. Importantly, Allah says 'farīqun' (a group), not 'kullu' (all), showing this was done by some People of the Book, not all. This is the Islamic principle of justice - not generalizing blame to everyone.

grammar.reason: Shows this group is FROM AMONG a larger category. This 'min' is partitive - meaning 'some of'.
grammar.practical: The preposition 'from' or 'from among'. Here it's partitive, meaning this group is part of a larger whole. 'Farīqun mina...' = 'a group FROM AMONG...' When you see this pattern, it indicates a subset. The word after 'min' takes kasrah (i ending).

grammar.reason: Introduces a description of who this group is from. Everything after explains their identity.
grammar.practical: Means 'those who' - starts a descriptive clause. It's plural masculine. Even though it's a pronoun, after the preposition 'min', the whole phrase acts in genitive. This introduces WHO the group is from - those who were given the Book. Use this to identify groups by their characteristics.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Past Tense Passive Verb (Fi'l Māḍī Majhūl)
grammar.root: أ-ت-ي (a-t-y) - to come, to bring, to give
grammar.reason: Passive voice shows they RECEIVED the book (didn't produce it themselves). The 'ū' at the end indicates plural masculine passive.
grammar.practical: Passive form meaning 'they were given'. From the root a-t-y (to bring/give). In active voice it would be 'ātū' (they gave), but here the pattern 'ūtū' shows passive: 'they WERE given'. The passive emphasizes that the Book was a GIFT from Allah - they received it, didn't author it. The 'ū' ending indicates plural masculine subjects in passive voice.

grammar.type: Ism - Noun (direct object/nā'ib al-fā'il in passive)
grammar.reason: In passive constructions, what would be the object becomes the stand-in subject (nā'ib al-fā'il), but it still takes accusative case. The 'a' ending marks this.
grammar.practical: Means 'the Book' - referring to the Torah and Injeel (Gospel). From k-t-b (to write). The 'a' ending (al-kitāba) shows accusative case. In the passive sentence 'they were given THE BOOK', the book is technically the object that was given, so it takes fatha. The 'al' makes it definite - THE Book, the divine scripture they possessed.

grammar.reason: This is what they threw - the direct object of 'nabadha'. It's in a possessive relationship with 'Allah' (the Book OF Allah). The 'a' ending shows it's the object being thrown.
grammar.practical: Same word 'kitāb' but now as the object of 'threw'. The 'a' ending shows this is WHAT they threw - the accusative case marks objects. No 'al' here because it's in iḍāfah (possessive construct) with 'Allah' - you can't have 'al' on the first word of iḍāfah. So instead of 'al-kitāb', it's 'kitāba Allāh' = 'the Book of Allah' or 'Allah's Book'.

grammar.reason: Second part of possessive construct (muḍāf ilayhi). The 'i' ending shows possession - Allah's Book.
grammar.practical: Allah's blessed name in genitive case (ending in 'i'). In the possessive phrase 'kitāba Allāhi' = 'Allah's Book', the second noun always takes kasrah. This emphasizes the severity of their action - they didn't just throw away any book, they threw away ALLAH'S BOOK! The iḍāfah construction adds emphasis and gravity.

grammar.root: و-ر-ي (w-r-y) - to be behind, to conceal
grammar.reason: Indicates WHERE they threw it - behind. Adverbs of place take accusative case. Metaphorically means to neglect completely.
grammar.practical: Means 'behind' - used for physical location and metaphorically for ignoring/neglecting. The 'a' ending is standard for adverbs of place. The phrase 'warā'a ẓuhūrihim' (behind their backs) is an Arabic idiom meaning to completely disregard or abandon something, to treat it as if it doesn't exist. Like we say in English 'turned their backs on it'.

grammar.reason: Forms possessive construct with 'warā'a'. The 'i' is due to the iḍāfah. 'Him' shows whose backs.
grammar.practical: Means 'their backs'. 'Ẓuhūr' is plural of 'ẓahr' (back). The 'i' ending is because it follows 'warā'a' in iḍāfah. The 'him' at the end = 'their'. Complete idiom: 'warā'a ẓuhūrihim' = 'behind their backs' = they completely abandoned it, treated it as if it was nothing. The plural 'backs' is used even for one person's back in formal Arabic.

grammar.type: Harf + Pronoun - Particle of Comparison (Harf Tashbīh) + Pronoun
grammar.function: 'Anna' and its sisters cause the noun to be accusative
grammar.reason: Creates a comparison or simile. 'Ka'anna' = 'as if' or 'as though'. The 'hum' is the subject in accusative case because of 'anna'.
grammar.practical: Powerful combination meaning 'as if they' or 'as though they'. 'Ka' = like/as, 'anna' = indeed, 'hum' = they. Together it creates a simile. This introduces a comparison of their state. Note: 'anna' is one of the special particles (inna and its sisters) that makes the subject accusative. Here 'hum' (they) would normally be nominative but takes accusative because of 'anna'.

grammar.reason: Negates their knowledge - as if they DON'T know.
grammar.practical: The negation particle 'not'. When it comes before a present-tense verb, it negates that action. So 'lā ya'lamūn' = 'they do not know'. This completes the simile: they act AS IF they don't know, though in reality they DO know.

grammar.reason: Describes ongoing state of knowledge. The 'ya...ūna' pattern indicates 'they' do the action in present tense.
grammar.practical: Means 'they know' from the root 'ilm (knowledge). The pattern 'ya'lamūna' follows the familiar 'ya...ūna' formula = 'they do' something (present tense). With 'lā' before it: 'lā ya'lamūn' = 'they don't know'. The verse implies they PRETEND not to know - they threw away Allah's book AS IF they were ignorant, but they actually knew it was the truth. This shows their willful rejection, not honest ignorance.

verses.arabic: وَاتَّبَعُوا مَا تَتْلُو الشَّيَاطِينُ عَلَىٰ مُلْكِ سُلَيْمَانَ ۖ وَمَا كَفَرَ سُلَيْمَانُ وَلَٰكِنَّ الشَّيَاطِينَ كَفَرُوا يُعَلِّمُونَ النَّاسَ السِّحْرَ وَمَا أُنزِلَ عَلَى الْمَلَكَيْنِ بِبَابِلَ هَارُوتَ وَمَارُوتَ ۚ وَمَا يُعَلِّمَانِ مِنْ أَحَدٍ حَتَّىٰ يَقُولَا إِنَّمَا نَحْنُ فِتْنَةٌ فَلَا تَكْفُرْ ۖ فَيَتَعَلَّمُونَ مِنْهُمَا مَا يُفَرِّقُونَ بِهِ بَيْنَ الْمَرْءِ وَزَوْجِهِ ۚ وَمَا هُم بِضَارِّينَ بِهِ مِنْ أَحَدٍ إِلَّا بِإِذْنِ اللَّهِ ۚ وَيَتَعَلَّمُونَ مَا يَضُرُّهُمْ وَلَا يَنفَعُهُمْ ۚ وَلَقَدْ عَلِمُوا لَمَنِ اشْتَرَاهُ مَا لَهُ فِي الْآخِرَةِ مِنْ خَلَاقٍ ۚ وَلَبِئْسَ مَا شَرَوْا بِهِ أَنفُسَهُمْ ۚ لَوْ كَانُوا يَعْلَمُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wattaba'ū mā tatlū ash-shayāṭīnu 'alā mulki Sulaymān, wa mā kafara Sulaymānu wa lākinna ash-shayāṭīna kafarū yu'allimūna an-nāsa as-siḥr, wa mā unzila 'ala al-malakayni bi-Bābila Hārūta wa Mārūt, wa mā yu'allimāni min aḥadin ḥattā yaqūlā innamā naḥnu fitnatun fa-lā takfur, fa-yata'allamūna minhumā mā yufarriqūna bihi bayna al-mar'i wa zawjihi, wa mā hum bi-ḍārrīna bihi min aḥadin illā bi-idhni Allāh, wa yata'allamūna mā yaḍurruhum wa lā yanfa'uhum, wa laqad 'alimū la-mani ishtarāhu mā lahu fī al-ākhirati min khalāq, wa labi'sa mā sharaw bihi anfusahum law kānū ya'lamūn
verses.translation: And they followed what the devils recited during the reign of Solomon. It was not Solomon who disbelieved, but the devils disbelieved, teaching people magic and that which was revealed to the two angels at Babylon, Harut and Marut. But they do not teach anyone unless they say, 'We are a trial, so do not disbelieve.' And they learn from them that by which they cause separation between a man and his wife. But they do not harm anyone through it except by permission of Allah. And they learn what harms them and does not benefit them. But they certainly knew that whoever purchased it would have no share in the Hereafter. And wretched is that for which they sold themselves, if they only knew

grammar.reason: Continues the description of what they did - they abandoned the Book AND followed something else.
grammar.practical: Simple conjunction 'and'. It adds to the previous verse's narrative: not only did they throw away Allah's book, they ALSO followed the devils. The 'wa' shows both actions happened.

grammar.reason: Describes what they did instead. The 'ū' ending shows plural masculine subject. Form VIII often indicates reflexive or intensive meaning.
grammar.practical: Means 'they followed' from t-b-' (to follow). The pattern 'ifta'alū' (Form VIII) becomes 'ittaba'ū' - the 't' doubles and merges. The 'ū' at the end marks plural past tense: 'they followed'. Form VIII adds intensity - they didn't just casually follow, they DEVOTED themselves to following. The shaddah (doubling) on the 'ta' is key to Form VIII recognition.

grammar.reason: Acts as the object of 'followed'. Everything after describes what 'mā' refers to.
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun meaning 'what' or 'that which'. It's the object of the verb 'followed' - they followed WHAT? The answer comes next. 'Mā' is very versatile in Arabic - can mean 'what', 'that which', or 'whatever' depending on context.

grammar.root: ت-ل-و (t-l-w) - to recite, to follow, to read
grammar.reason: Describes what the devils recite/narrate. The 'ta...ū' pattern with feminine singular subject.
grammar.practical: From t-l-w meaning 'to recite' or 'to narrate'. Same root as 'tilāwah' (recitation of Quran). The pattern 'tatlū' = 'she/it recites' - third person feminine singular present tense. Though devils (shayāṭīn) is plural, the verb is singular feminine because 'shayāṭīn' is treated as a group/collective. The verse refers to what the devils used to recite or spread.

grammar.root: ش-ط-ن (sh-ṭ-n) - to be far removed (from mercy)
grammar.reason: Subject of the verb 'tatlū'. The 'u' ending marks nominative case for subjects.
grammar.practical: Means 'the devils' - plural of 'shayṭān' (devil/satan). The broken plural form 'shayāṭīn' follows the pattern 'fayā'īl'. The 'u' ending (ash-shayāṭīnu) shows it's the subject doing the reciting. The root sh-ṭ-n means 'to be far away' - devils are far from Allah's mercy. Broken plurals don't follow regular patterns - you memorize them individually.

grammar.root: ع-ل-و ('a-l-w) - to be high, to be above
grammar.reason: Here means 'concerning' or 'in the time of'. Makes the following word genitive.
grammar.practical: The preposition ''alā' usually means 'on/upon' but here means 'concerning' or 'during'. What the devils recited CONCERNING Solomon's reign. After ''alā', the next word takes kasrah (i ending). The alif maqṣūrah (ā) at the end is a special form of alif that looks different at the end of words.

grammar.root: م-ل-ك (m-l-k) - to own, to rule, to possess
grammar.reason: In possessive relationship with 'Sulaymān'. The 'i' is from the preposition ''alā'.
grammar.practical: Means 'kingdom', 'reign', or 'sovereignty' from m-l-k (to rule/own). Same root as 'malik' (king). The 'i' ending is because of ''alā'. No 'al' because it's in iḍāfah with Solomon's name next. 'Mulki Sulaymān' = 'Solomon's kingdom' or 'the reign of Solomon'.

grammar.reason: Foreign/proper name that doesn't take tanwīn. In iḍāfah with 'mulk'. Shows whose reign.
grammar.practical: Prophet Solomon's name (Sulaymān in Arabic). As the second part of iḍāfah, it's in genitive case. Notice it doesn't have tanwīn - proper names of foreign origin (and certain patterns) are diptotes (don't take tanwīn and have special case endings). Here 'Sulaymāna' with fatha serves as genitive. The verse refers to the reign of Prophet Solomon (peace be upon him).

grammar.reason: Begins a statement denying something about Solomon. 'Mā' is negation particle used before verbs.
grammar.practical: Combination of 'wa' (and) + 'mā' (not). Together they introduce a strong denial: 'and NOT'. This 'mā' negates past tense verbs. The verse is about to defend Prophet Solomon against false accusations.

grammar.root: ك-ف-ر (k-f-r) - to disbelieve, to cover, to reject
grammar.reason: Describes an action being denied. The 'a' ending is standard for past tense.
grammar.practical: From k-f-r meaning 'to disbelieve' or 'to cover the truth'. The pattern 'fa'ala' is basic Form I past tense = 'he disbelieved'. But with 'mā' before it, it's negated: 'mā kafara' = 'he did NOT disbelieve'. This defends Prophet Solomon - the devils spread lies about him practicing magic, but Allah declares his innocence.

grammar.reason: Subject of the verb 'kafara'. The 'u' ending marks nominative case.
grammar.practical: Prophet Solomon's name as the subject. The 'u' ending (Sulaymānu) shows he's the subject - the one about whom we're saying 'did NOT disbelieve'. As a diptote, it takes just dammah (u) without tanwīn for nominative. This verse is crucial - it absolves Prophet Solomon from accusations of practicing magic or disbelief.

grammar.function: 'Lākinna' is one of 'inna and its sisters'
grammar.reason: Introduces a contrast. 'Lākinna' makes the following noun accusative. Contrasts Solomon (who didn't disbelieve) with the devils (who did).
grammar.practical: Powerful combination meaning 'but' or 'however'. 'Lākinna' (also spelled 'lākin' when not followed by a noun) is one of the 'inna sisters' - particles that cause the subject to be accusative. The shaddah on the 'n' is essential. Used to make a strong contrast: Solomon DIDN'T disbelieve, BUT the devils DID.

grammar.reason: Subject placed in accusative case by 'lākinna'. The 'a' ending shows this.
grammar.practical: Same word 'devils' but now ending in 'a' (ash-shayāṭīna) instead of 'u'. Why? Because 'lākinna' is one of those special particles that puts its subject in accusative case. Remember the 'inna sisters' (inna, anna, lākinna, ka'anna, etc.) always do this. So while normally a subject takes 'u', after lākinna it takes 'a'.

grammar.reason: The predicate (khabar) of 'lākinna'. Describes what the devils did. The 'ū' shows plural.
grammar.practical: Same root k-f-r but now with plural ending 'ū' = 'they disbelieved'. This is the predicate telling us WHAT the devils did. Clear contrast: Solomon DIDN'T disbelieve (mā kafara Sulaymān), BUT the devils DID disbelieve (lākinna ash-shayāṭīna kafarū). The shayāṭīn committed kufr, not the noble prophet!

grammar.reason: Describes HOW they committed kufr - by teaching magic. Form II indicates intensive/causative: making others know = teaching.
grammar.practical: From 'ilm (knowledge). Form II pattern 'yu'allimūna' = 'they teach'. The doubling of the middle letter (shaddah on 'l') is the hallmark of Form II, which often means 'to make someone do' the root meaning. So from ''alima' (he knew), we get ''allama' (he taught/made someone know). The 'yu...ūna' pattern = they do it (present tense). This explains their kufr - teaching people magic.

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'teach' - they teach WHOM? The people. Accusative case marked by fatha.
grammar.practical: Means 'the people' or 'mankind'. The 'a' ending (an-nāsa) marks it as the direct object - they teach THE PEOPLE. Always remember: objects take fatha. 'Nās' is an irregular noun - it doesn't follow standard patterns. It refers to human beings collectively. The devils taught PEOPLE magic - spreading corruption among humanity.

grammar.reason: Second direct object - they teach people WHAT? Magic. Takes accusative case.
grammar.practical: Means 'magic' or 'sorcery' from s-ḥ-r (to deceive/bewitch). The 'a' ending shows it's the object - they teach the people MAGIC. The 'al' makes it definite - THE magic, the specific forbidden knowledge. Siḥr refers to practices that deceive the senses and often invoke jinn or devils. Islam strictly prohibits learning or practicing magic.

grammar.function: Adds another object to what they taught
grammar.reason: Continues listing what the devils taught - magic AND what was revealed to the two angels.
grammar.practical: Means 'and what' or 'and that which'. The 'wa' adds to the list, and 'mā' introduces the next item. They taught people magic AND ALSO what was revealed to the two angels. This 'mā' is a relative pronoun acting as another object of 'teach'.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Past Tense Passive Verb (Fi'l Māḍī Majhūl)
grammar.root: ن-ز-ل (n-z-l) - to descend, to send down
grammar.reason: Passive voice - something WAS revealed (we're not focusing on who revealed it). The 'u-i' vowel pattern marks passive.
grammar.practical: From n-z-l meaning 'to descend'. Form IV 'anzala' = 'to send down/reveal' (active). In passive it becomes 'unzila' = 'was sent down/revealed'. The 'u' at the beginning and 'i' in the middle are the passive markers. Used for revelation - knowledge sent down. This refers to knowledge given to the two angels as a test for people.

grammar.reason: Shows TO WHOM it was revealed - to the two angels.
grammar.practical: Preposition ''alā' meaning 'upon' or 'to'. Here it shows the recipients of revelation - revealed TO the two angels. After ''alā', the next word takes kasrah.

grammar.reason: Dual form because it's specifically two angels. After preposition, dual takes 'ayni' ending.
grammar.practical: Means 'the two angels'. From 'malak' (angel). In Arabic, dual (exactly two) has special endings: -āni (nominative) or -ayni (genitive/accusative). Here 'al-malakayni' ends in 'ayni' because it follows the preposition ''alā'. Dual is beautiful in Arabic - a separate number category between singular and plural! The 'al' before dual keeps the 'al' + dual ending.

grammar.reason: Indicates WHERE the angels were - in Babylon. The 'bi' shows location.
grammar.practical: Means 'in Babylon'. 'Bi' = at/in, 'Bābil' = Babylon (ancient city in Iraq). The preposition 'bi' makes Babylon genitive. As a foreign proper name, Bābil is a diptote (doesn't take tanwīn). The angels Harut and Marut were sent to this specific location. Babylon was historically known for magical practices.

grammar.reason: Specifies the names of the two angels. Acts as apposition (badal) to 'the two angels'.
grammar.practical: The name of the first angel: Harut. This is in apposition to 'the two angels' - specifying WHO they are. As a foreign proper name, it's a diptote. The fatha ending serves for genitive case here. Harut and Marut were angels sent as a test - they would teach magic but only after warning people not to misuse it.

grammar.reason: The second angel's name, completing the pair.
grammar.practical: Means 'and Marut' - the second angel's name. Connected with 'wa' to Harut. Together 'Hārūta wa Mārūta' = 'Harut and Marut'. These two angels were sent to teach people magic as a TRIAL, but they always warned people first, as we'll see in the next part of the verse.

grammar.reason: Introduces a negation about what the two angels do.
grammar.practical: Conjunction plus negation = 'and not'. Starts a new clause about what the angels DON'T do. Despite having knowledge of magic, they don't teach it carelessly.

grammar.reason: Dual form because it refers to the two angels specifically. The 'āni' ending marks dual.
grammar.practical: Form II meaning 'to teach' in DUAL form! From ''allama' (to teach). The ending 'āni' indicates TWO subjects doing the action. This is the dual present tense pattern. Compare: yu'allimūna (they teach - plural) vs. yu'allimāni (they two teach - dual). The dual form precisely refers to Harut and Marut - exactly two angels.

grammar.function: Here means 'any' (min zā'idah - extra min for emphasis)
grammar.reason: With negation and 'aḥad', emphasizes 'not anyone at all'.
grammar.practical: The preposition 'min' but used in a special way. With negation + min + aḥad, it means 'not ANY one' - complete negation. This 'min' emphasizes the totality of the negation: they don't teach ANYONE at all (without warning first). It's called 'min zā'idah' (extra min) - it's there for emphasis.

grammar.reason: With negation, means 'anyone' or 'not a single person'. The 'in' ending is due to 'min'.
grammar.practical: Means 'anyone' or 'someone'. From the root w-ḥ-d (one). With negation: 'mā yu'allimāni min aḥadin' = 'they don't teach anyone'. The 'in' ending (aḥadin) is because of the preposition 'min'. Together with the negation, it's emphatic: not A SINGLE PERSON do they teach (without warning).

grammar.reason: Introduces the condition that must be met before they teach - they must warn first.
grammar.practical: Particle meaning 'until' or 'unless'. It sets a limit or condition. The angels don't teach anyone UNLESS/UNTIL they first say the warning. 'Ḥattā' indicates the endpoint or condition that must be reached. It can be followed by either a verb or a noun.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') - Subjunctive
grammar.reason: Dual form for the two angels. Subjunctive mood (marked by 'a' ending) because of 'ḥattā'.
grammar.practical: From q-w-l (to say). The dual form 'yaqūlā' = 'they two say'. The 'ā' ending instead of 'āni' shows it's in subjunctive mood (manṣūb), which happens after 'ḥattā'. Compare: yaqūlāni (indicative dual) vs. yaqūlā (subjunctive dual). The subjunctive shows this is the condition/purpose - they don't teach UNTIL they say...

grammar.type: Harf - Particle of Emphasis and Restriction
grammar.function: Strong emphasis and limitation: 'we are ONLY'
grammar.reason: Combined particle that emphasizes and restricts. The 'mā' cancels inna's grammatical effect.
grammar.practical: Powerful combination: 'inna' (indeed) + 'mā' = 'innamā' (only/merely/nothing but). When 'mā' is added to 'inna', it cancels the grammatical effect (doesn't make the subject accusative) but adds restriction. So 'innamā naḥnu...' = 'we are ONLY...' or 'we are nothing but...'. It's emphatic restriction - limiting the statement strongly.

grammar.reason: Subject of the sentence - the angels speaking about themselves.
grammar.practical: First person plural pronoun 'we'. The angels speaking about themselves: 'WE are...' Usually after 'inna' the subject would be accusative, but because of the 'mā' in 'innamā', the subject stays nominative. 'Naḥnu' is the independent pronoun for 'we'.

grammar.root: ف-ت-ن (f-t-n) - to test, to try, to tempt
grammar.reason: The predicate (khabar) describing what 'we' are. The 'un' ending marks nominative case for predicates.
grammar.practical: Means 'a trial', 'a test', or 'a temptation'. From f-t-n (to test/try). The 'un' ending makes it the predicate: 'we are A TRIAL'. This is the angels' warning - they're not teaching magic for people to use, but as a TEST of faith. The tanwīn emphasizes the meaning. 'Fitnah' can mean trial, temptation, or tribulation - anything that tests faith.

grammar.function: 'Fa' shows result, 'lā' with imperative creates prohibition
grammar.reason: 'Fa' indicates consequence: SINCE we are a trial, THEREFORE don't disbelieve.
grammar.practical: Combination of 'fa' (so/therefore) + 'lā' (not). Together = 'so do not' or 'therefore don't'. The 'fa' shows logical consequence - SINCE we're a trial, THEREFORE don't fall into it. When 'lā' comes before a present tense verb (in jussive mood), it creates a negative command: 'don't do X!'

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') - Jussive
grammar.reason: With 'lā', forms negative command: 'don't disbelieve!' The jussive mood (no final vowel) indicates prohibition.
grammar.practical: From k-f-r (to disbelieve). The pattern 'takfur' = 'you disbelieve' (second person). With 'lā' before it, becomes a prohibition: 'lā takfur' = 'don't disbelieve!' The jussive mood is shown by the absence of a final vowel (sukūn on the 'r'). This is the angels' crucial warning: we'll teach you, but DON'T USE IT TO COMMIT KUFR! The warning shows magic is forbidden knowledge that can lead to disbelief.

words.translation: so they learn / but they learn

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Present Tense Verb
grammar.reason: 'Fa' introduces result. Form V means 'to learn for oneself' - reflexive. The 'ūna' shows plural.
grammar.practical: Means 'so they learn' or 'but they learn'. From 'ilm (knowledge). Form V 'tafa''ala' pattern creates reflexive meaning: 'ta'allama' = 'to learn' (to teach oneself). The pattern 'yata'allamūna' = 'they learn'. The 'fa' is adversative here - DESPITE the warning, they still learn. The shaddah on the 'l' and the 'ta' prefix are markers of Form V.

grammar.reason: Shows the source of learning - FROM the two angels specifically.
grammar.practical: Means 'from them two'. 'Min' = from, 'humā' = them (dual). The 'ā' ending on the pronoun indicates dual - referring specifically to the two angels, Harut and Marut. So people learn FROM THE TWO ANGELS. The dual pronoun precisely refers back to the dual subject mentioned earlier.

grammar.reason: Object of 'learn' - they learn WHAT? The following clause explains.
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun 'what' or 'that which'. It's the object - they learn WHAT? The answer comes in the next part: what causes separation. 'Mā' introduces the description of this harmful knowledge.

grammar.reason: Describes the effect of what they learn. Form II adds intensity - causing separation.
grammar.practical: From f-r-q (to separate). Form II 'farraq' means 'to cause separation' or 'to separate intensely'. Pattern 'yufarriqūna' = 'they cause separation'. The shaddah on the 'r' is the Form II marker. This describes the evil purpose - they learn magic TO SEPARATE people, specifically spouses. The present tense shows this is their ongoing practice.

grammar.reason: Shows the MEANS of separation - BY MEANS OF this magic. The 'hi' refers to the magic learned.
grammar.practical: Means 'by it' or 'with it'. 'Bi' = by/with (instrument), 'hi' = it (referring to the magic). So they cause separation BY MEANS OF IT - using the magic as a tool. This shows magic is the instrument of harm. The 'bi' indicates the tool or method used.

grammar.root: ب-ي-ن (b-y-n) - to be between, to be clear
grammar.function: Shows the space or relationship between two things
grammar.reason: Indicates BETWEEN WHOM the separation occurs. Always takes accusative case.
grammar.practical: Means 'between' - shows relationship or space between two entities. 'Bayna' is a ẓarf (adverb of place) that always takes fatha (a ending) and is always in iḍāfah with what comes after. It requires TWO things - between X and Y. Here it sets up: separation BETWEEN whom? The husband and wife.

grammar.reason: First party in the 'between' relationship. Takes kasrah due to iḍāfah with 'bayna'.
grammar.practical: Means 'the man' or specifically 'the husband' in this context. From m-r-' (man/person). The 'i' ending (al-mar'i) is because it follows 'bayna' in iḍāfah. 'Mar'' is a somewhat formal/classical word for man. The verse describes separation between THE MAN and his wife - highlighting the family-destroying nature of this evil magic.

grammar.reason: Second party in the 'between' relationship. The 'i' is due to 'bayna', and 'hi' shows possession.
grammar.practical: Means 'and his wife/spouse'. From z-w-j (pair/spouse) - the word for spouse in Arabic. The 'i' ending is because of 'bayna'. The suffix 'hi' = 'his', referring back to 'the man'. 'Zawjihi' = his spouse. Complete phrase: 'bayna al-mar'i wa zawjihi' = between the man and his wife. This shows the target of this evil magic - destroying marriages and families!

grammar.reason: Introduces a limitation on their power - they can't actually harm anyone.
grammar.practical: Means 'and not' or 'but not'. The 'wa' continues the description, and 'mā' negates. This starts an important theological point about the limitation of magic's power.

grammar.reason: Subject of the negation - THEY are not the ones harming.
grammar.practical: Third person plural pronoun 'they' - referring to those who practice magic. Acts as the subject: THEY are not... The independent pronoun adds emphasis to the subject.

grammar.reason: The 'bi' here is extra (bi zā'idah) for emphasis. The active participle describes a state of harming.
grammar.practical: Means 'harmers' or 'ones causing harm'. From ḍ-r-r (to harm). The pattern 'ḍārrīn' is active participle (like fā'il) meaning 'one who harms'. The 'īna' ending shows plural masculine in genitive case (after 'bi'). The 'bi' here is called 'extra bi' (bi zā'idah) - it's there for emphasis but doesn't change the meaning. So 'mā hum bi-ḍārrīna' = 'they are not ones who (can) harm'.

grammar.reason: Shows the MEANS - by means of magic. The 'hi' refers to the magic.
grammar.practical: Means 'by it' or 'with it' - referring to the magic. They're not able to harm anyone BY MEANS OF the magic. Even though they practice it, they cannot cause actual harm through it (without Allah's permission, as the verse continues).

grammar.function: Extra min for emphasis: 'not any one'
grammar.reason: With negation, emphasizes totality: not anyone at all.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'min' used for emphasis in negation. With 'mā' (not) + 'min' + 'aḥad' = 'not ANY one at all'. The 'min' strengthens the negation - not a single person can they harm.

grammar.reason: With negation and 'min', means 'not a single person'.
grammar.practical: Means 'anyone' or 'one'. The 'in' ending is from 'min'. Complete phrase: 'mā hum bi-ḍārrīna bihi min aḥadin' = 'they cannot harm anyone by it' - meaning magicians cannot actually harm anyone with magic... BUT there's an exception coming!

grammar.function: Introduces an exception to the negation
grammar.reason: After negation, introduces the only condition under which harm can occur.
grammar.practical: Particle of exception meaning 'except' or 'unless'. After a negation, 'illā' introduces the ONE exception. They can't harm anyone EXCEPT (in one case)... Creates anticipation for the condition that follows.

grammar.reason: Shows the CONDITION - only with permission. The 'i' is from 'bi'.
grammar.practical: Means 'by permission of'. From a-dh-n (to permit). 'Idhn' = permission. The 'bi' shows instrumentality - BY MEANS OF permission. The 'i' ending is because of 'bi'. It's in iḍāfah with Allah's name next. This is the crucial theological point: magic has NO power except what Allah permits!

grammar.reason: Second part of iḍāfah - Allah's permission. The 'i' shows possession.
grammar.practical: Allah's blessed name in genitive: Allāhi. In the iḍāfah 'bi-idhni Allāhi' = 'by the permission of Allah'. This is a fundamental Islamic belief: NOTHING happens except by Allah's will and permission. Magic has no independent power - any effect it has is only because Allah permits it as part of His divine wisdom. This verse removes all power from magicians and affirms Allah's absolute control!

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Present Tense Verb
grammar.reason: Continues describing what they do. Form V = to learn (for oneself).
grammar.practical: Means 'and they learn'. Same Form V verb we saw earlier: 'yata'allamūna' = they learn. The 'wa' adds another point about their foolishness - they keep learning more harmful knowledge.

grammar.reason: Introduces WHAT they learn - harmful things.
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun 'what' - they learn WHAT? The description comes next: what harms them.

grammar.reason: Describes the nature of what they learn - it HARMS them. The 'hum' shows whom it harms.
grammar.practical: Means 'it harms them'. From ḍ-r-r (to harm). 'Yaḍurru' = it harms, 'hum' = them. Together = it harms them. The double 'r' (shaddah) is part of this root. They foolishly learn what actually HARMS themselves - magic damages their faith, brings punishment, and ruins their afterlife. They think they're gaining power but they're destroying themselves!

grammar.reason: Continues the description - it harms them AND it doesn't benefit them.
grammar.practical: Means 'and not'. Adds to the description of this harmful knowledge - not only does it HARM them, but it also does NOT benefit them. Double loss!

grammar.root: ن-ف-ع (n-f-') - to benefit, to be useful
grammar.reason: With 'lā', means 'it does NOT benefit them'. The 'hum' shows whom it doesn't benefit.
grammar.practical: Means 'it benefits them'. From n-f-' (to benefit). 'Yanfa'u' = it benefits, 'hum' = them. With 'lā' before it: 'lā yanfa'uhum' = it does NOT benefit them. What a tragic situation - they pursue something that HARMS them and brings them NO BENEFIT! The verse emphasizes the utter foolishness of choosing magic over divine guidance.

grammar.reason: 'La' + 'qad' together create very strong emphasis: 'most certainly'.
grammar.practical: Powerful combination meaning 'and certainly' or 'and indeed'. 'La' is for emphasis, 'qad' with past tense adds certainty. Together 'laqad' emphasizes the truth of what comes next - they DEFINITELY knew! This makes their choice even more condemnable.

grammar.reason: With 'laqad', emphasizes they CERTAINLY knew. The 'ū' shows plural.
grammar.practical: Means 'they knew' from 'ilm (knowledge). The pattern ''alimū' = they knew (past tense). With 'laqad' before it: 'wa laqad 'alimū' = 'and they certainly knew'. This condemns them - they weren't ignorant, they KNEW the consequences but chose magic anyway!

grammar.reason: Introduces what they knew - WHOEVER does something (buys magic).
grammar.practical: Combination meaning 'surely whoever' or 'certainly who'. 'La' is for emphasis (oath-like), 'man' (different from min) is a relative pronoun meaning 'whoever' or 'who'. Together: they certainly knew that WHOEVER... The 'i' on 'mani' is because it will be followed by the verb.

grammar.reason: Describes the action - whoever 'bought' or 'exchanged for' magic. The 'hu' refers to magic.
grammar.practical: Means 'he purchased it'. From sh-r-y (to buy). Form VIII 'ishtarā' = he bought/purchased. The 'hu' = it (referring to magic). Together = whoever purchased it. 'Buying' magic metaphorically means exchanging truth for falsehood, trading away one's faith for worldly tricks. The Form VIII indicates a completed transaction - they made a terrible deal!

grammar.reason: Begins the consequence - what such a person will NOT have.
grammar.practical: Negation particle 'not'. Introduces what the magic-buyer will NOT have. This sets up the severe consequence of choosing magic.

grammar.reason: Indicates FOR WHOM there is nothing - for him/whoever bought magic.
grammar.practical: Means 'for him'. 'La' (for/to) + 'hu' (him). Shows possession or entitlement. 'Mā lahu' = there is not for him, he does not have. Refers back to whoever bought magic - HE will not have...

grammar.reason: Specifies WHERE he has nothing - in the next life.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'in' - indicates location. The loss is not in this world but IN the Hereafter, which is infinitely worse! After 'fī', the next word takes kasrah.

grammar.reason: Refers to the next life, the final abode. The 'i' ending is due to 'fī'.
grammar.practical: Means 'the Hereafter' or 'the Last Life'. From a-kh-r (last/final). 'Al-ākhirah' is the standard term for the afterlife in Islam - as opposed to 'al-dunyā' (this world). The 'i' ending (al-ākhirati) is because of 'fī'. The verse specifies the REAL loss - not worldly loss, but loss IN THE HEREAFTER, in eternity!

grammar.reason: With negation, emphasizes: not ANY share at all.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'min' used for emphasis in negation. 'Mā lahu fī al-ākhirati min khalāq' = he has NOT ANY share in the Hereafter. The 'min' strengthens the negation - absolutely zero portion.

grammar.root: خ-ل-ق (kh-l-q) - to create; also means share/portion
grammar.reason: Means 'share' or 'portion'. With negation: no share at all in the Hereafter.
grammar.practical: Means 'share', 'portion', or 'lot'. From kh-l-q (though different meaning from 'creation'). The 'in' ending is from 'min'. 'Khalāq' specifically means one's allotted share or portion. The complete phrase: whoever buys magic has NO SHARE in the Hereafter - meaning they lose Paradise, they have no reward, no success in the afterlife. This is total spiritual bankruptcy!

words.translation: and how wretched / and how evil

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Verb of Praise/Blame
grammar.root: ب-ئ-س (b-'-s) - to be wretched, to be evil
grammar.function: 'Bi'sa' is a special verb used to express strong condemnation
grammar.reason: Expresses extreme disapproval. 'La' adds oath-like emphasis.
grammar.practical: Powerful expression meaning 'how wretched!' or 'how evil!' 'Bi'sa' is a special frozen verb (doesn't conjugate normally) used only for strong condemnation. With 'la' it becomes 'labi'sa' = extremely wretched! It's the opposite of 'ni'ma' (how excellent!). This construction introduces what is being condemned.

grammar.function: Subject of the condemnation - WHAT is wretched
grammar.reason: Introduces what is being condemned as wretched.
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun 'what' or 'that which'. After 'bi'sa', it introduces WHAT is being condemned: wretched is WHAT? The answer: what they sold themselves for.

grammar.root: ش-ر-ي (sh-r-y) - to buy or to sell (can mean either)
grammar.reason: Describes what they did - they 'sold' or 'exchanged'. The 'aw' ending shows plural past.
grammar.practical: From sh-r-y which can mean both 'to buy' AND 'to sell' depending on context. Here 'sharaw' = they sold/exchanged. The 'aw' ending indicates third person plural past tense. They SOLD their souls - exchanged their faith and afterlife for temporary magic tricks. Same root as earlier 'ishtarā' but different form and meaning!

grammar.reason: Shows the PRICE they sold for - they sold themselves FOR magic.
grammar.practical: Means 'for it' or 'with it'. 'Bi' = for/with, 'hi' = it (magic). They sold themselves IN EXCHANGE FOR it - trading their eternal souls for magic. The 'bi' shows the price or exchange: sold FOR this.

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'sold' - they sold WHAT? Their own souls. The 'a' marks accusative.
grammar.practical: Means 'their souls' or 'themselves'. 'Anfus' is plural of 'nafs' (soul/self). The 'a' ending (anfusahum) shows it's the object - they sold THEIR SOULS. The 'hum' = their. Complete: 'sharaw bihi anfusahum' = they sold their souls for it. Tragic trade - exchanging eternal salvation for temporary illusions! The verse condemns this as the worst possible transaction.

grammar.reason: Expresses a contrary-to-fact condition. Implies the condition is NOT met.
grammar.practical: 'Law' introduces a hypothetical unfulfilled condition meaning 'if only' or 'if (but they don't)'. It implies the opposite is true. 'Law kānū ya'lamūn' = if only they knew... BUT they don't! It expresses regret or irony - if only they had real knowledge, they wouldn't have done this.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Past Tense Verb (Fi'l Māḍī) - Verb of Being
grammar.reason: Auxiliary verb 'to be' - creates continuous/conditional meaning. The 'ū' shows plural.
grammar.practical: Means 'they were' or 'they had been'. From k-w-n (to be/exist). 'Kānū' = they were (past tense plural). With 'law', it creates the condition: 'if they had been...' It's an auxiliary verb that makes what follows continuous or conditional.

grammar.reason: With 'kānū' creates: 'if they had knowledge' or 'if they really knew'. The present after kāna indicates continuous state.
grammar.practical: Means 'they know'. From 'ilm (knowledge). The pattern 'ya'lamūna' = they know. With 'law kānū ya'lamūna': 'if only they had real knowledge' or 'if only they really knew'. The verse ends with devastating irony - they thought they were gaining secret knowledge through magic, but if they had REAL knowledge (of consequences, of Allah's truth), they would never have chosen this path. Their pursuit of 'knowledge' led to ultimate ignorance!

verses.arabic: وَلَوْ أَنَّهُمْ آمَنُوا وَاتَّقَوْا لَمَثُوبَةٌ مِّنْ عِندِ اللَّهِ خَيْرٌ ۖ لَّوْ كَانُوا يَعْلَمُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa law annahum āmanū wattaqaw la-mathūbatun min 'indi Allāhi khayrun law kānū ya'lamūn
verses.translation: And if they had believed and feared Allah, then the reward from Allah would have been better, if they only knew

grammar.reason: Contrasts with their actual choice. 'Law' implies they DIDN'T do this.
grammar.practical: Means 'and if' but with the implication that the condition wasn't met. The 'wa' connects to the previous verse, and 'law' introduces a contrary-to-fact condition: IF ONLY they had believed (but they didn't). It expresses what could have been.

grammar.reason: After 'law', 'anna' introduces the subject of the condition.
grammar.practical: Combination meaning 'that they'. 'Anna' is one of the 'inna sisters' that causes the subject to be accusative. 'Hum' (they) is in accusative because of 'anna'. Together with 'law': 'if they had...' The 'anna' transforms the sentence structure after 'law'.

grammar.root: أ-م-ن (a-m-n) - to believe, to have faith
grammar.reason: Describes the first condition - if they had believed. The 'ū' shows plural.
grammar.practical: Means 'they believed' from a-m-n (faith/belief). Form IV 'āmanū' = they believed. This is the first condition of what they SHOULD have done - instead of following magic, they should have BELIEVED in Allah and His messenger. The past tense with 'law' creates the unfulfilled conditional mood.

words.translation: and they had taqwa / feared Allah

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb
grammar.root: و-ق-ي (w-q-y) - to protect, to guard, to fear Allah
grammar.reason: Second condition - belief AND taqwa together. The 'aw' ending shows plural past.
grammar.practical: Means 'and they had taqwa' or 'and they feared Allah'. From w-q-y (to protect/guard). Form VIII 'ittaqaw' becomes 'attaqaw' with the 'wa' attached = 'wattaqaw'. The 'aw' ending = they (plural, past). Second condition: not just belief, but TAQWA - consciousness of Allah, protecting yourself from His displeasure. These two (īmān and taqwā) are the foundations of Islamic life!

grammar.reason: The 'la' is the answer to 'law' (called lām al-jawāb). Mathūbah is the subject.
grammar.practical: Means 'surely a reward'. 'La' is the emphatic particle answering the 'law' condition - IF they had done that, THEN surely a reward... From th-w-b (to return/reward). 'Mathūbah' means reward or recompense. The 'un' ending marks it as the subject (nominative). The tanwīn emphasizes: a MAGNIFICENT reward!

grammar.reason: Shows WHERE the reward comes from - from Allah.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' indicating source. The reward comes FROM Allah. After 'min', the next word takes kasrah (i ending). The shaddah on mīm is for recitation emphasis.

grammar.root: ع-ن-د ('a-n-d) - to be near, in the presence of
grammar.reason: Together with 'min': 'from the presence of'. The 'i' is from the preposition.
grammar.practical: Means 'with' or 'at'. The 'i' ending is because of 'min'. Together 'min 'indi' = 'from with' or 'from the presence of'. Emphasizes the divine source of this reward - not from worldly means, but FROM ALLAH'S PRESENCE!

grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with ''ind'. The 'i' shows possession.
grammar.practical: Allah's blessed name in genitive case (Allāhi). In the construct 'min 'indi Allāhi' = 'from Allah' or 'from the presence of Allah'. This emphasizes that TRUE reward comes from Allah, not from magic or other false sources!

grammar.reason: Predicate describing the reward - it IS better. The 'un' marks nominative.
grammar.practical: Means 'better' or 'best' from kh-y-r (good). The pattern 'khayrun' is the comparative form (like 'akbar' from 'kabīr'). The 'un' ending makes it the predicate: the reward IS better. Better than what? Better than magic, better than any worldly gain! The verse contrasts: they chose magic, but Allah's reward would have been INFINITELY better!

grammar.reason: Repeats the regret - if only they knew.
grammar.practical: Same 'law' (if) that we saw before. Used again for emphasis and regret: IF ONLY they knew (but they don't). This repetition drives home the tragedy - they're acting in ignorance of what's truly better for them. The shaddah on the lām is for clear pronunciation in recitation.

grammar.reason: Auxiliary verb creating continuous meaning with the following verb.
grammar.practical: Means 'they were' from k-w-n (to be). With 'law': 'if they had been...' Creates the conditional state. Arabic uses 'kāna' to add continuous or conditional aspect to verbs.

grammar.reason: With 'law kānū': 'if only they knew'. Expresses unfulfilled condition.
grammar.practical: From 'ilm (knowledge). Pattern 'ya'lamūna' = they know. Complete phrase 'law kānū ya'lamūna' = 'if only they really knew!' The verse ends emphasizing their ignorance - they THINK they're gaining knowledge through magic, but they don't REALLY know what's better. True knowledge would have led them to faith and taqwa, not magic!

verses.arabic: يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا لَا تَقُولُوا رَاعِنَا وَقُولُوا انظُرْنَا وَاسْمَعُوا ۗ وَلِلْكَافِرِينَ عَذَابٌ أَلِيمٌ
verses.transliteration: Yā ayyuhā alladhīna āmanū lā taqūlū rā'inā wa qūlū unẓurnā wasma'ū wa lil-kāfirīna 'adhābun alīm
verses.translation: O you who have believed, do not say rā'inā but say unẓurnā and listen. And for the disbelievers is a painful punishment

grammar.reason: Used to call out to someone, to get their attention.
grammar.practical: The vocative particle 'O'. Used to call someone: 'O you!' In English we might say 'Hey' or 'O', but in Arabic 'yā' is the respectful, formal way to address someone. When you see 'yā', a direct address is coming. The Quran frequently uses 'yā ayyuhā alladhīna āmanū' (O you who believe) to address the believers directly.

grammar.reason: After 'yā', this combination means 'O you' - emphasizing and directing attention.
grammar.practical: Combination of 'ayyu' (which one) + 'hā' (attention particle). Together with 'yā': 'yā ayyuhā' = 'O you!' The 'hā' is purely for attention and emphasis. This construction is used before an adjective or description to call out to a specific group. Here it will be followed by 'those who believe'.

grammar.reason: Describes WHO is being addressed - those who (believe).
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun 'those who'. It starts the description of the people being addressed. Whatever comes after defines them. This familiar pattern: 'yā ayyuhā alladhīna āmanū' = 'O you who have believed' is one of the most frequent phrases in the Quran, appearing 89 times! It's Allah's direct address to the believers.

grammar.reason: Defines who 'those who' are - those who BELIEVED. Past tense but means ongoing state.
grammar.practical: From a-m-n (faith). Form IV 'āmanū' = they believed/have believed. The past tense here indicates completed action that has lasting effect - they believed and continue to be believers. So the address is: 'O you who have believed!' - speaking directly to the Muslims. Whenever you see this phrase in the Quran, a command or teaching for believers follows.

grammar.function: Creates negative command with following verb
grammar.reason: Prohibits the believers from doing something.
grammar.practical: Prohibition particle 'do not'. With the following verb in jussive mood, creates a prohibition: 'don't do X!' This 'lā' is specifically for commands (lā an-nāhiyah). After addressing the believers lovingly, Allah gives them guidance about what NOT to do.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') - Jussive
grammar.reason: With 'lā', creates prohibition: 'do not say'. Jussive mood shown by no final nūn.
grammar.practical: From q-w-l (to say). Pattern 'taqūlū' (second person plural present) = 'you say'. With 'lā' before it: 'lā taqūlū' = 'don't say!' The jussive mood deletes the final nūn (would be 'taqūlūna' in indicative). Notice: the Quran doesn't just prohibit actions, but even prohibits certain WORDS that might cause confusion or disrespect!

grammar.root: ر-ع-ي (r-'-y) - to observe, to shepherd; or to be foolish
grammar.reason: This word was misused by hypocrites. In Arabic it could mean 'observe us' but also sounded like Hebrew word for 'foolish'.
grammar.practical: This word means 'observe us' or 'pay attention to us' in Arabic, from r-'-y (to observe/shepherd). The 'nā' = us. So literally 'rā'inā' = 'observe us'. BUT the Jews used this word mockingly because it sounded similar to a Hebrew insult meaning 'our foolishness' or 'listen, fool'. They used it as a play on words to insult the Prophet ﷺ while pretending to speak respectfully. Allah prohibits this word to close the door to such disrespect!

grammar.reason: Positive command: SAY this instead. The 'wa' adds the alternative instruction.
grammar.practical: Means 'and say' or 'but say instead'. From q-w-l (to say). The pattern 'qūlū' is the imperative plural: 'you all, say!' Notice how the Quran prohibits one word but immediately provides an ALTERNATIVE - not just 'don't say X' but 'say Y instead'. This is beautiful Islamic pedagogy - replacing bad with good!

words.translation: look at us / give us your attention

grammar.root: ن-ظ-ر (n-ẓ-r) - to look, to wait, to give attention
grammar.reason: The proper alternative to 'rā'inā'. Same meaning but without ambiguity.
grammar.practical: Means 'look at us' or 'give us your attention'. From n-ẓ-r (to look/observe). 'Unẓur' = look! (command), 'nā' = us. Together 'unẓurnā' = 'look at us' or 'wait for us' or 'give us your attention'. This has the SAME respectful meaning as 'rā'inā' was intended to have, but without the potential for mockery. The Muslims are taught to say 'unẓurnā' instead when asking the Prophet to wait or pay attention!

grammar.root: س-م-ع (s-m-') - to hear, to listen, to obey
grammar.reason: Additional command: not only say the right words, but truly LISTEN.
grammar.practical: Means 'and listen' from s-m-' (to hear/listen). The pattern 'isma'ū' becomes 'wasma'ū' with the conjunction. This is imperative plural: 'you all, listen!' In Arabic, 'sam'' means both 'to hear' and 'to obey' - true listening leads to obedience. The verse teaches: use proper words AND truly listen to the Prophet's teachings!

grammar.reason: Introduces a warning about the disbelievers. The 'īna' is genitive plural after 'li'.
grammar.practical: Means 'and for the disbelievers'. 'Kāfirīn' (active participle plural from k-f-r) = those who disbelieve/reject. The 'īna' ending shows genitive plural after the preposition 'li' (for). 'Li + al' combines to 'lil'. This sets up the subject: FOR THE DISBELIEVERS (there is)... The contrast is clear: believers are given guidance, but disbelievers face consequences.

grammar.reason: Subject of the implied 'there is'. The 'un' marks nominative case.
grammar.practical: Means 'punishment' or 'torment' from 'a-dh-b (to punish). The 'un' ending makes it the subject: (there is) a punishment. The tanwīn makes it indefinite but emphatic - A punishment (of significant magnitude). 'Adhāb refers to severe punishment, suffering, or torment. This is the consequence for those who disbelieve and mock.

grammar.root: أ-ل-م (a-l-m) - to be painful, to hurt
grammar.reason: Describes the punishment - it is PAINFUL. The 'un' matches ''adhābun' (both nominative).
grammar.practical: Means 'painful' or 'agonizing' from a-l-m (pain). The pattern 'fa'īl' (here 'alīm') often indicates intensive quality - extremely painful. The 'un' ending matches the noun it describes (both nominative, both indefinite). Complete phrase: ''adhābun alīmun' = a painful punishment. This is one of the common Quranic phrases describing the punishment of disbelievers - not just any punishment, but a deeply PAINFUL one.

verses.arabic: مَّا يَوَدُّ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا مِنْ أَهْلِ الْكِتَابِ وَلَا الْمُشْرِكِينَ أَن يُنَزَّلَ عَلَيْكُم مِّنْ خَيْرٍ مِّن رَّبِّكُمْ ۗ وَاللَّهُ يَخْتَصُّ بِرَحْمَتِهِ مَن يَشَاءُ ۚ وَاللَّهُ ذُو الْفَضْلِ الْعَظِيمِ
verses.transliteration: Mā yawaddu alladhīna kafarū min ahli al-kitābi wa lā al-mushrikīna an yunazzala 'alaykum min khayrin min rabbikum, wa Allāhu yakhtaṣṣu bi-raḥmatihi man yashā', wa Allāhu dhū al-faḍli al-'aẓīm
verses.translation: Neither those who disbelieve from the People of the Scripture nor the polytheists wish that any good should be sent down to you from your Lord. But Allah selects for His mercy whom He wills, and Allah is the possessor of great bounty

grammar.reason: Strong negation - they do NOT wish this.
grammar.practical: Negation particle 'not'. Used before verbs to negate them. The shaddah on the mīm is for clear recitation. Sets up a negative statement about what the disbelievers wish.

grammar.root: و-د-د (w-d-d) - to wish, to love, to desire
grammar.reason: Describes ongoing state of NOT wishing. The shaddah on the 'd' is part of the root.
grammar.practical: From w-d-d meaning 'to wish' or 'to love/desire'. The pattern 'yawaddu' (with doubled 'd') = 'he wishes'. With 'mā' before it: 'mā yawaddu' = 'he does not wish'. The present tense shows this is their continuous state - they consistently do NOT wish good for believers. The root has geminate (doubled) consonants which is reflected in the shaddah.

grammar.reason: Subject of the verb 'yawaddu' - WHO doesn't wish? Those who...
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun 'those who'. It's the subject doing the (not) wishing. Starts a description - those who (did what?). The following verb explains.

grammar.reason: Defines who 'alladhīna' refers to - those who disbelieved.
grammar.practical: From k-f-r (to disbelieve/reject). Pattern 'kafarū' = they disbelieved. So 'alladhīna kafarū' = those who disbelieved/the disbelievers. The past tense indicates completed action with lasting state - they disbelieved and remain disbelievers.

grammar.reason: Shows this group is FROM AMONG a larger category.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' used partitively. 'Min ahli' = from among the people. This specifies which disbelievers - particularly those FROM the People of the Book. After 'min', the next word takes kasrah.

grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with 'the Book'. The 'i' is from 'min'.
grammar.practical: Means 'people' or 'folk'. The 'i' ending is because of 'min'. No 'al' because it's in iḍāfah. 'Ahlu al-kitāb' = People of the Book. 'Ahl' refers to people associated with something - here, people associated with previous scripture (Jews and Christians).

grammar.reason: In possessive relationship with 'ahl'. The 'i' shows possession.
grammar.practical: Means 'the Book' from k-t-b (to write). The 'i' ending (al-kitābi) is because it's in iḍāfah with 'ahl'. Complete phrase: 'min ahli al-kitābi' = from among the People of the Book. This term refers to Jews and Christians who received previous scriptures (Torah and Gospel).

grammar.reason: Continues the negation to include another group - NOR the polytheists.
grammar.practical: Means 'and not' or 'nor'. Adds to the list of those who don't wish good for believers. The 'wa' connects, and 'lā' extends the negation: NEITHER the People of the Book NOR...

grammar.root: ش-ر-ك (sh-r-k) - to associate partners, to share
grammar.reason: Second group that doesn't wish good. Ends in 'īna' (could be genitive continuing from 'min', or accusative as second subject).
grammar.practical: Means 'the polytheists' or 'those who associate partners with Allah'. From sh-r-k (to share/associate). Form IV 'ashrak' = to commit shirk (associating partners with Allah). Active participle 'mushrik' = one who commits shirk. Plural 'mushrikīn'. The 'īna' ending shows plural masculine. Complete: NEITHER the People of the Book NOR the polytheists wish good for you!

grammar.function: Introduces what they don't wish - makes verb into verbal noun
grammar.reason: Creates the object of 'wish' - they don't wish THAT...
grammar.practical: Particle 'that' which introduces a verbal noun clause. After 'yawaddu' (wishes), 'an' introduces WHAT they don't wish. 'Mā yawaddu... an yunazzala' = they don't wish THAT it be sent down. 'An' converts the following verb into a verbal noun concept.

words.translation: it should be sent down / be revealed

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Passive Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri' Majhūl) - Subjunctive
grammar.root: ن-ز-ل (n-z-l) - to descend, to send down
grammar.reason: What they don't wish - they don't wish that good BE SENT DOWN. Passive shows something being sent. Subjunctive after 'an'.
grammar.practical: From n-z-l (to descend). Form II 'nazzala' = to send down (intensive/repetitive). Passive 'yunazzala' = it is sent down/revealed. The 'u-a' vowel pattern marks passive voice. After 'an', it's in subjunctive mood (ends in 'a'). They don't wish that revelation/good BE SENT DOWN to you. The passive emphasizes the divine act of sending down.

grammar.reason: Shows TO WHOM they don't want good sent - to YOU (the believers).
grammar.practical: Means 'upon you' or 'to you'. ''Alā' = upon/to, 'kum' = you (plural). Together ''alaykum' = to you all. Shows the target of revelation: they don't want good revealed TO YOU. The plural 'kum' addresses all the believers. This reveals their jealousy and hatred!

grammar.reason: With negation, emphasizes: not ANY good at all.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' but used here as 'extra min' for emphasis. In negation, 'min' before the object strengthens it: they don't want ANY good at all. The shaddah on mīm is for recitation. This 'min' emphasizes the totality of their ill-will.

grammar.reason: Object of what they don't wish - ANY good. The 'in' is from 'min'.
grammar.practical: Means 'good' or 'goodness' from kh-y-r. The 'in' ending (khayrin) is because of 'min'. With the negation and 'min': they don't want ANY good (whatsoever) to come to you! 'Khayr' can mean good, goodness, or benefit. This includes revelation, guidance, worldly blessings - they want NONE of it for the believers!

grammar.reason: Shows WHERE the good comes from - from your Lord.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' indicating source. The good that they don't want you to have comes FROM (a mighty source). This 'min' introduces the divine source of blessings.

grammar.root: ر-ب-ب (r-b-b) - to lord, to sustain, to nurture
grammar.reason: Shows the source of good - from YOUR Lord. The possessive emphasizes the relationship.
grammar.practical: Means 'your Lord'. 'Rabb' = Lord/Sustainer/Nurturer from r-b-b. The 'i' ending is from 'min'. The 'kum' = your (plural). Together 'rabbikum' = your Lord. The possessive is powerful - YOUR Lord (who cares for YOU) wants to give you good, but your enemies don't want you to have it. Beautiful contrast! The shaddah on the rā' is for recitation emphasis.

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Conjunction + Proper Noun (Divine Name)
grammar.reason: New sentence begins - AND Allah... The 'u' marks it as the subject.
grammar.practical: Means 'and Allah'. The conjunction 'wa' starts a new clause, and 'Allāhu' (with dammah 'u') is the subject of the new sentence. After describing what the disbelievers wish, now we learn what ALLAH does - a powerful contrast!

grammar.root: خ-ص-ص (kh-ṣ-ṣ) - to specify, to particularize, to select
grammar.reason: Describes Allah's ongoing action - He SELECTS. The shaddah on ṣād is from Form VIII pattern.
grammar.practical: From kh-ṣ-ṣ (to specify/select). Form VIII 'ikhtaṣṣa' = to select for oneself, to single out. Pattern 'yakhtaṣṣu' = He selects/specifies. The doubling of ṣād (shaddah) is key to Form VIII of this root. This shows Allah's sovereignty - regardless of what the disbelievers wish, ALLAH selects whom He wills for His mercy!

words.translation: with His mercy / for His mercy

grammar.root: ر-ح-م (r-ḥ-m) - to have mercy, to be compassionate
grammar.reason: Shows WHAT He selects people for - for His mercy. The 'bi' indicates the means or object.
grammar.practical: Means 'with/for His mercy'. 'Raḥmah' = mercy from r-ḥ-m (mercy/compassion). The 'i' ending (raḥmatihi) is from 'bi'. The 'hi' = His. Together: He selects people FOR His mercy. The 'bi' here indicates what He singles people out for. This is the ultimate blessing - being selected for Allah's raḥmah (mercy)!

grammar.function: Object of the verb - He selects WHOM?
grammar.reason: Indicates the object of selection - WHOM He selects.
grammar.practical: Relative pronoun 'whom' or 'whoever'. This is the object - He selects WHOM? The answer: whom He wills. 'Man' can mean 'who' or 'whoever' depending on context. Here it's the object of Allah's selection.

grammar.reason: Describes Allah's will - He selects whom He WILLS. Present tense shows ongoing divine will.
grammar.practical: From sh-y-' (to will/wish). Pattern 'yashā'u' = He wills/wishes. Complete phrase: 'yakhtaṣṣu bi-raḥmatihi man yashā'' = He selects for His mercy whomever He wills. This affirms Allah's absolute sovereignty - His mercy is His to give as He wills. No one's jealousy or hatred can stop Allah's will!

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Conjunction + Proper Noun (Divine Name)
grammar.reason: Begins final statement of the verse. The 'u' marks the subject.
grammar.practical: Means 'and Allah'. Starts the concluding statement. Allah's name repeated for emphasis - the verse began with what enemies don't want, middle showed what Allah does, now ends with WHO Allah is!

grammar.type: Ism - Noun (one of the five nouns)
grammar.form: One of the 'five nouns' with special endings
grammar.reason: Predicate describing Allah - He IS the possessor of. The 'ū' is the nominative form of 'dhū'.
grammar.practical: Means 'possessor of' or 'owner of'. 'Dhū' is one of the five special nouns in Arabic that have unique case endings: 'dhū' (nominative), 'dhī' (genitive), 'dhā' (accusative). Here it's nominative as the predicate. Used in iḍāfah: 'dhū al-faḍl' = possessor of bounty. This word emphasizes OWNERSHIP and ABUNDANCE.

grammar.root: ف-ض-ل (f-ḍ-l) - to exceed, to favor, to be gracious
grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with 'dhū'. Shows WHAT Allah possesses - bounty/grace.
grammar.practical: Means 'bounty', 'grace', or 'favor' from f-ḍ-l (to exceed/favor). The 'i' ending (al-faḍli) is because of iḍāfah with 'dhū'. 'Dhū al-faḍl' = Possessor of bounty/grace. 'Faḍl' means abundance, extra blessings, unearned favor - Allah has infinite grace to give!

grammar.root: ع-ظ-م ('a-ẓ-m) - to be great, to be magnificent
grammar.reason: Describes 'al-faḍl' - the bounty is GREAT. The 'i' matches the noun it describes.
grammar.practical: Means 'the Great' or 'the Magnificent' from 'a-ẓ-m (to be great). The pattern 'fa'īl' (here ''aẓīm') indicates intensive quality. The 'i' ending (al-'aẓīmi) matches 'al-faḍli' (both genitive). Complete: 'dhū al-faḍli al-'aẓīm' = Possessor of the Great Bounty. Allah's grace isn't limited - it's 'AẒĪM (MAGNIFICENT)! The verse ends with this powerful divine attribute, contrasting the pettiness of the disbelievers with the magnificence of Allah!

verses.arabic: مَا نَنسَخْ مِنْ آيَةٍ أَوْ نُنسِهَا نَأْتِ بِخَيْرٍ مِّنْهَا أَوْ مِثْلِهَا ۗ أَلَمْ تَعْلَمْ أَنَّ اللَّهَ عَلَىٰ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ
verses.transliteration: Mā nansakh min āyatin aw nunsihā na'ti bi-khayrin minhā aw mithlihā, alam ta'lam anna Allāha 'alā kulli shay'in qadīr
verses.translation: We do not abrogate a verse or cause it to be forgotten except that We bring forth one better than it or similar to it. Do you not know that Allah is over all things competent?

grammar.reason: Can mean 'not' or 'whatever' depending on context. Here creates negative conditional.
grammar.practical: Particle that can mean 'not' or 'whatever'. In this context with the verb pattern, it creates a negative statement: We do NOT abrogate... OR it can mean 'whatever We abrogate'. The meaning encompasses both - any abrogation that happens follows this rule.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') - Jussive
grammar.root: ن-س-خ (n-s-kh) - to abrogate, to copy, to abolish
grammar.reason: Allah speaking about His action of abrogating verses. The 'na' prefix indicates 'We'.
grammar.practical: From n-s-kh meaning 'to abrogate', 'to copy', or 'to supersede'. The pattern 'nansakh' = 'We abrogate'. The 'na' at the beginning means 'We' (Allah using royal/majestic plural). Abrogation (naskh) in Islamic law means when a later revelation supersedes or modifies an earlier ruling. This is Allah's prerogative as the Lawgiver!

grammar.reason: Indicates 'any verse' or 'from among verses'.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' used partitively. With indefinite noun after it, means 'any' - any verse from among verses. After 'min', the next word takes kasrah.

grammar.reason: Object of abrogation - ANY verse. The 'in' is from 'min'.
grammar.practical: Means 'a verse' or 'a sign' from a-y-y. The 'in' ending (āyatin) is because of 'min'. 'Āyah' in Quran context means a verse, but it literally means 'a sign' - each verse is a sign from Allah. The tanwīn makes it indefinite: any verse. This verse discusses the concept of naskh (abrogation) where Allah may replace one ruling with another.

grammar.reason: Presents second option - abrogate OR cause to be forgotten.
grammar.practical: Conjunction meaning 'or'. Presents an alternative action: We abrogate a verse OR... The 'aw' gives options or alternatives.

words.translation: We cause it to be forgotten

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Alternative to abrogation - causing a verse to be forgotten. Form IV makes it causative.
grammar.practical: From n-s-y (to forget). Form IV 'ansā' = to cause to forget, to make forgotten. Pattern 'nunsī' = We cause to forget. The 'hā' = it (referring to the verse). Together 'nunsihā' = We cause it to be forgotten. Form IV is causative - not 'We forget' but 'We MAKE it forgotten'. This could mean removing from memory or from application. The verse shows two divine prerogatives: abrogating OR causing to be forgotten.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') - Jussive
grammar.reason: Main clause after the condition - We BRING (as replacement). Jussive after conditional.
grammar.practical: From a-t-y (to bring/come). Pattern 'na'tī' shortened to 'na'ti' in jussive = We bring. The 'na' prefix = We. This is the consequence clause: (Whatever We abrogate), We BRING a replacement. The jussive mood (dropping the yā') shows this is the result of the condition. Allah never takes away without giving something better!

grammar.reason: Shows WHAT We bring - something better. The 'bi' indicates accompaniment.
grammar.practical: Means 'with better' or 'something better'. 'Khayr' = good/better from kh-y-r. The 'in' ending (bi-khayrin) is from 'bi'. The 'bi' shows what accompanies the bringing - We bring WITH/something better. The replacement verse is BETTER than what was abrogated - either easier to practice, more comprehensive in ruling, or more suited to the community's development!

grammar.reason: Shows comparison - better THAN what? Than it (the abrogated verse).
grammar.practical: Means 'than it' or 'from it'. 'Min' = from/than (used for comparison), 'hā' = it (referring to the abrogated verse). Together 'minhā' = than it. Complete phrase: 'bi-khayrin minhā' = with something better than it. The 'min' is used for comparison in Arabic - like 'better THAN'.

grammar.reason: Second option for replacement - better OR similar.
grammar.practical: Conjunction 'or'. Presents the alternative: We bring something better than it OR... Shows the replacement is at least equal, never inferior!

grammar.root: م-ث-ل (m-th-l) - to resemble, to be similar
grammar.reason: Alternative to 'better' - at minimum, the replacement is SIMILAR/equal. The 'i' is from being in construct.
grammar.practical: Means 'similar to it' or 'its like'. 'Mithl' = likeness/similar from m-th-l. The 'i' ending (mithlihā) is from being in iḍāfah with the pronoun. The 'hā' = it. Complete: 'aw mithlihā' = or similar to it. So the replacement is either BETTER or AT LEAST EQUAL - never worse! This shows Allah's wisdom and mercy in legislation.

grammar.reason: Rhetorical question expecting 'yes' answer: Don't you know? (Of course you know!)
grammar.practical: Powerful combination meaning 'Do not...' or 'Did not...' in a question. 'A' makes it a question, 'lam' negates past tense. Together 'alam' = 'Did not...?' or 'Do not...?' This is rhetorical - not asking for information but making a point. 'Alam ta'lam' = Don't you know? (implying: you SHOULD know!). It's a gentle reminder.

grammar.type: Fi'l - Present Tense Verb (Fi'l Muḍāri') - Jussive
grammar.reason: After 'lam', present tense becomes jussive and means past. The 'ta' shows 'you'.
grammar.practical: From 'ilm (knowledge). Pattern 'ta'lam' = you know. After 'lam', it becomes jussive and takes past meaning: 'you did not know' or 'don't you know?' The 'ta' prefix indicates second person (you). Complete question: 'alam ta'lam' = Don't you know? This addresses the Prophet ﷺ or any reader - don't you know Allah's power?

grammar.type: Harf - Particle (one of inna and sisters)
grammar.function: Introduces the object of knowledge, makes subject accusative
grammar.reason: After 'know', introduces WHAT you should know: that Allah...
grammar.practical: Particle 'that' - one of the 'inna sisters'. Introduces what you should know. After verbs of knowing, 'anna' brings the content: you know THAT... Makes the following noun (Allah's name) accusative. This 'anna' is crucial for sentence structure after verbs of cognition.

grammar.reason: Subject in accusative case because of 'anna'. Shows ABOUT WHOM we should know.
grammar.practical: Allah's blessed name in accusative case (Allāha with fatha). After 'anna', the subject takes accusative instead of nominative. So it's 'anna Allāha' = that Allah... This is the content of knowledge - you should know THAT ALLAH (has this quality).

grammar.reason: Shows Allah's power OVER something.
grammar.practical: Preposition ''alā' meaning 'over' or 'upon'. In context of power, means Allah has power OVER. After ''alā', the next word takes kasrah.

grammar.type: Ism - Noun (quantifier, first part of iḍāfah)
grammar.reason: Means 'every' or 'all'. In iḍāfah with 'thing' - every thing. The 'i' is from ''alā'.
grammar.practical: Means 'every' or 'all' from k-l-l (totality). The 'i' ending (kulli) is because of ''alā'. No 'al' because it's in iḍāfah with the next word. 'Kullu shay'' = everything, all things. This word emphasizes TOTALITY - not some things, but EVERY thing!

grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with 'kull'. Together = every thing. The 'in' shows genitive.
grammar.practical: Means 'thing' from sh-y-' (to be/exist as thing). The 'in' ending (shay'in) is because of iḍāfah with 'kull'. Together 'kulli shay'in' = every thing, everything. This phrase encompasses ABSOLUTE totality - every single thing that exists or can exist!

grammar.root: ق-د-ر (q-d-r) - to be able, to have power
grammar.reason: Predicate of 'anna' sentence - Allah IS capable. The 'un' marks nominative for predicate.
grammar.practical: Means 'capable', 'powerful', or 'all-able' from q-d-r (power/ability). The pattern 'fa'īl' (here 'qadīr') indicates intensive, permanent quality - COMPLETELY capable, ALWAYS able. The 'un' ending (qadīrun) marks it as the predicate (khabar of anna). Complete: 'anna Allāha 'alā kulli shay'in qadīr' = that Allah is capable over everything. This is one of Allah's most important attributes - Al-Qadīr (The All-Powerful). The verse ends by grounding the discussion of abrogation in Allah's absolute power!

verses.arabic: أَلَمْ تَعْلَمْ أَنَّ اللَّهَ لَهُ مُلْكُ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضِ ۗ وَمَا لَكُم مِّن دُونِ اللَّهِ مِن وَلِيٍّ وَلَا نَصِيرٍ
verses.transliteration: Alam ta'lam anna Allāha lahu mulku as-samāwāti wal-arḍ, wa mā lakum min dūni Allāhi min waliyyin wa lā naṣīr
verses.translation: Do you not know that to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and that you have not besides Allah any protector or any helper?

grammar.reason: Creates emphatic rhetorical question expecting affirmative answer.
grammar.practical: Same structure as verse 106 - 'alam' creates a rhetorical question meaning 'Don't you know?' or 'Do you not know?' It's not really asking, but emphasizing that you SHOULD know this truth!

grammar.reason: After 'lam', takes jussive mood and past meaning.
grammar.practical: From 'ilm (knowledge). 'Ta'lam' = you know. With 'alam': Don't you know? Addresses the listener directly - don't YOU know this fundamental truth?

grammar.function: Introduces content of knowledge, makes subject accusative
grammar.reason: Shows WHAT you should know.
grammar.practical: Particle 'that' introducing the object of knowledge. Don't you know THAT... Makes the following noun (Allah) accusative.

grammar.reason: Subject after 'anna' takes accusative case.
grammar.practical: Allah's name in accusative (Allāha). After 'anna', subjects take fatha. This introduces WHO we're learning about.

grammar.reason: Indicates TO WHOM the dominion belongs.
grammar.practical: Means 'to Him' or 'for Him'. 'La' = for/to, 'hu' = Him (Allah). 'Lahu' emphasizes possession and entitlement - TO HIM belongs...

grammar.reason: Subject/predicate after 'anna' - what belongs to Allah. Nominative as predicate.
grammar.practical: Means 'sovereignty' or 'dominion' from m-l-k (to rule/own). Same root as 'malik' (king). The 'u' ending marks nominative. No 'al' because it's in iḍāfah with what follows. The SOVEREIGNTY belongs to Him!

grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with 'mulk'. Shows dominion OVER WHAT.
grammar.practical: Means 'the heavens'. Plural of 'samā'' (sky/heaven). The 'i' ending (as-samāwāti) is from iḍāfah. 'Mulku as-samāwāt' = the dominion/sovereignty of the heavens. The broken plural 'samāwāt' doesn't follow regular plural patterns.

grammar.reason: Conjoined with 'heavens' in the iḍāfah. Both in genitive.
grammar.practical: Means 'and the earth'. 'Al-arḍ' = the earth from a-r-ḍ. The 'i' ending (wal-arḍi) is from the iḍāfah continuing.
