Complete phrase: 'mulku as-samāwāti wal-arḍ' = the sovereignty of the heavens and the earth. This classic Quranic phrase encompasses ALL existence - everything above and everything here!

grammar.reason: Introduces what believers DON'T have.
grammar.practical: Means 'and not'. After affirming Allah's total sovereignty, now states what we DON'T have. The 'wa' connects, 'mā' negates.

grammar.reason: Addresses the believers - YOU don't have...
grammar.practical: Means 'for you'. 'La' = for, 'kum' = you (plural). Together 'lakum' = for you all. There is NOT for you...

grammar.reason: With negation, emphasizes totality - not ANY protector.
grammar.practical: Extra 'min' for emphasis. With negation: you don't have ANY (at all). The shaddah on mīm is for recitation.

grammar.type: Ẓarf - Adverbial noun (first part of iḍāfah)
grammar.reason: Means 'besides' or 'other than'. In iḍāfah with Allah.
grammar.practical: Means 'besides', 'other than', or 'apart from'. The 'i' ending is from 'min'. 'Dūn' indicates exclusion - besides this, other than this. No 'al' because it's in iḍāfah.

grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with 'dūn' - besides Allah.
grammar.practical: Allah's name in genitive (Allāhi). In the phrase 'min dūni Allāhi' = besides Allah, other than Allah. Emphasizes exclusivity - there is NO protector OTHER THAN ALLAH!

grammar.reason: Repeated 'min' to emphasize negation - not ANY protector at all.
grammar.practical: Another 'min' for emphasis. The repetition strengthens the negation - not ANY protector whatsoever!

grammar.root: و-ل-ي (w-l-y) - to be close, to protect
grammar.reason: What you don't have - no protector. The 'in' is from 'min'.
grammar.practical: Means 'protector', 'guardian', or 'ally' from w-l-y (to be near/protect). The 'in' ending (waliyyin) is from 'min'. 'Walī' is someone who protects, supports, and helps. You have NO walī besides Allah - no one can truly protect or support you except Him!

grammar.reason: Extends negation to another category - NOR a helper.
grammar.practical: Means 'and not' or 'nor'. Adds to the negation - you have no protector AND no helper either!

grammar.root: ن-ص-ر (n-ṣ-r) - to help, to support, to give victory
grammar.reason: Second thing you don't have - no helper. Genitive continuing the structure.
grammar.practical: Means 'helper' or 'supporter' from n-ṣ-r (to help/support). Pattern 'naṣīr' (fa'īl) indicates intense helping. The 'in' ending is genitive. 'Naṣīr' is someone who helps you achieve victory or success. The verse declares: besides Allah, you have NO protector (walī) and NO helper (naṣīr). This is both humbling (we're completely dependent) and comforting (Allah is sufficient)!

verses.arabic: أَمْ تُرِيدُونَ أَن تَسْأَلُوا رَسُولَكُمْ كَمَا سُئِلَ مُوسَىٰ مِن قَبْلُ ۗ وَمَن يَتَبَدَّلِ الْكُفْرَ بِالْإِيمَانِ فَقَدْ ضَلَّ سَوَاءَ السَّبِيلِ
verses.transliteration: Am turīdūna an tas'alū rasūlakum kamā su'ila Mūsā min qabl, wa man yatabaddali al-kufra bil-īmāni fa-qad ḍalla sawā'a as-sabīl
verses.translation: Or do you intend to ask your Messenger as Moses was asked before? And whoever exchanges faith for disbelief has certainly strayed from the soundness of the way

grammar.reason: Creates challenging rhetorical question - OR do you want to do this foolish thing?
grammar.practical: Interrogative particle meaning 'or' in questions. Can mean 'or do you...?' or 'rather, do you...?' Used to present an alternative, often with implied criticism. Here it challenges: OR do you intend to make unreasonable demands like previous nations did?

grammar.root: ر-و-د (r-w-d) - to want, to desire, to intend
grammar.reason: Asks about their intention - do YOU want to...? The 'ūna' shows plural.
grammar.practical: From r-w-d (to want). Form IV 'arāda' = to want/intend. Pattern 'turīdūna' = you (plural) want/intend. The 'tu' prefix shows second person, 'ūna' ending shows plural present tense. Challenges them: do you REALLY want to do this?

grammar.reason: Introduces what they want - to ask. Makes it the object of 'want'.
grammar.practical: Particle 'that' or 'to'. After 'want', introduces the intended action: you want TO ask... 'An' with the verb creates a verbal noun concept - the action of asking.

grammar.reason: What they intend to do - to ASK. Subjunctive after 'an'.
grammar.practical: From s-'-l (to ask). Pattern 'tas'alū' (shortened from tas'alūna) = you ask. In subjunctive mood after 'an' (drops the nūn). You want TO ASK - but ask what? Unreasonable demands, like previous nations!

grammar.reason: Whom they would ask - YOUR messenger. The possessive emphasizes relationship.
grammar.practical: Means 'your messenger'. 'Rasūl' = messenger from r-s-l (to send). The 'a' ending (rasūlakum) marks accusative - he's the one being asked. 'Kum' = your (plural). YOUR messenger (Muhammad ﷺ) - emphasizes the relationship and trust that should exist, making unreasonable demands even more inappropriate!

grammar.reason: Compares their potential action to what happened before - JUST AS Moses was asked.
grammar.practical: Means 'as' or 'just as'. 'Ka' = like, 'mā' = what/that which. Together 'kamā' = just as, in the same way as. Creates comparison: you want to ask your messenger JUST AS (people asked Moses before). Links their behavior to historical precedent!

grammar.reason: Passive voice - Moses WAS asked (unreasonable questions). The 'u-i' pattern marks passive.
grammar.practical: From s-'-l (to ask). Passive form 'su'ila' = he was asked. The 'u' at beginning and 'i' in middle are passive markers. Moses WAS ASKED (by his people) - they made unreasonable demands for physical signs and miracles out of stubbornness, not sincere seeking.

grammar.reason: Subject of passive verb - Moses was the one asked.
grammar.practical: Prophet Moses's name (Mūsā in Arabic). As subject of passive verb 'su'ila', Moses is who was asked. The name doesn't take tanwīn (diptote). The reference is to how the Children of Israel made excessive, inappropriate demands of Moses (like demanding to see Allah directly, asking unnecessary questions about the cow, etc.).

grammar.reason: Shows time reference - FROM before, in the past.
grammar.practical: Preposition 'from' indicating temporal starting point. With 'qabl' (before), creates 'min qabl' = from before, previously, in the past.

grammar.reason: Time reference - BEFORE (in the past). With 'min' creates temporal phrase.
grammar.practical: Means 'before' from q-b-l (prior/before). 'Qabl' is an adverb of time. With 'min': 'min qablu' = from before, previously, in earlier times. Complete phrase: as Moses was asked FROM BEFORE - referring to how previous nations made unreasonable demands of their prophets. This is a warning not to repeat their mistakes!

grammar.reason: Shifts to universal statement about WHOEVER does something wrong.
grammar.practical: Means 'and whoever'. 'Man' = whoever/who. This introduces a general rule: AND WHOEVER (does the following)... The statement applies to anyone who commits this action.

grammar.root: ب-د-ل (b-d-l) - to change, to exchange, to substitute
grammar.reason: Describes the action - whoever EXCHANGES. Form V adds reflexive meaning. Jussive in conditional.
grammar.practical: From b-d-l (to change/exchange). Form V 'tabaddala' = to exchange, to substitute (for oneself). Pattern 'yatabaddal' = he exchanges. The 'ta' prefix and doubled 'd' mark Form V. Jussive mood (no i'rāb) because it's in a conditional 'man' clause. The action of exchanging one thing for another!

grammar.reason: What is being taken IN the exchange - disbelief. Object takes accusative.
grammar.practical: Means 'disbelief' or 'rejection' from k-f-r. The 'a' ending (al-kufra) marks accusative - it's the object of exchange. 'Kufr' is the verbal noun meaning disbelief, covering the truth, rejecting faith. This is what they TAKE in the bad exchange.

words.translation: for faith / in place of faith

grammar.reason: The 'bi' shows exchange - disbelief IN PLACE OF faith. Shows what they give up.
grammar.practical: Means 'for faith' or 'in place of faith'. 'Īmān' = faith/belief from a-m-n. The 'i' ending (bil-īmāni) is from 'bi'. The 'bi' here indicates exchange/substitution. Complete phrase: whoever exchanges disbelief FOR faith - meaning gives up faith and takes disbelief instead. A terrible, losing trade!

grammar.reason: 'Fa' shows result, 'qad' emphasizes certainty. THEN he has CERTAINLY...
grammar.practical: Powerful combination meaning 'then certainly' or 'has indeed'. 'Fa' introduces the result/consequence, 'qad' with past tense emphasizes certainty. Whoever does the exchange, THEN he has DEFINITELY... The consequence is sure!

grammar.root: ض-ل-ل (ḍ-l-l) - to go astray, to be lost, to err
grammar.reason: The consequence - he has GONE ASTRAY. Past tense with 'qad' shows completed action with lasting effect.
grammar.practical: From ḍ-l-l (to go astray/be lost). Pattern 'ḍalla' = he went astray. With 'fa-qad': he has CERTAINLY gone astray. The doubled 'l' (shaddah) is part of this root. 'Ḍalāl' (going astray) is the opposite of guidance (hudā). This person has lost the path completely!

grammar.root: س-و-ي (s-w-y) - to be level, straight, sound
grammar.reason: Specifies HOW he went astray - from the SOUNDNESS. Accusative of specification.
grammar.practical: Means 'soundness', 'straightness', or 'right way' from s-w-y (to be level/straight). The 'a' ending (sawā'a) marks accusative as specification (tamyīz). It specifies the TYPE of straying - he strayed FROM the SOUNDNESS/rightness of the path. 'Sawā'' indicates balance, levelness, correctness.

grammar.reason: In iḍāfah with 'sawā'' - the soundness OF the path.
grammar.practical: Means 'the way' or 'the path' from s-b-l. The 'i' ending (as-sabīli) is from iḍāfah with 'sawā''. Complete phrase: 'sawā'a as-sabīl' = the soundness of the path, the right way, the straight path. 'As-sabīl' in Quran often refers to the path of Islam, the way to Allah. The verse declares: whoever exchanges faith for disbelief has gone completely astray from the straight path!
